thread.title: Texts may show blackmail attempt of former Trump campaign chair
thread.title_full: Texts may show blackmail attempt of former Trump campaign chair

author: JASON SILVERSTEIN
title: Texts may show blackmail attempt of former Trump campaign chair
text:
Hacked texts show alleged Ukrainian blackmail attempt on former Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort Texts may show blackmail attempt of former Trump campaign chair NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Updated: Thursday, February 23, 2017, 11:42 AM 
President Trump’s former campaign chair Paul Manafort may have been the target of a blackmail attempt by a Ukrainian parliament member, according to a report on Thursday. 
A potential cyber hack of Manafort’s daughter’s phone revealed texts allegedly showing Ukrainian parliamentarian member Serhiy Leshchenko threatening to expose damaging information about Manafort and Trump, Politico reported. 
One text allegedly shows Leshchenko boasting of “bulletproof facts” revealing Manafort’s financial ties to former Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych, as well as his role in arranging a meeting between Trump and an associate of Yanukovych. 
The texts claim Yanukovych was “rendering assets” to Manafort for consulting services. It also says Trump — called “Donadl Trump” in the text — met the Yanukovych associate in June 2012. 
Three FBI inquiries into Russian election hacking 
It threatens to expose this information to the FBI and to the National Anti-Corruption Bureau of Ukraine. 
“Considering all the facts and evidence that are in my possession, and before possible decision whether to pass this to NABU or FBI I would like to get your opinion on this and maybe your way to work things out that will persuade me to do otherwise,” the text says. It does not specify the conditions for the apparent blackmail. 
Another text, from a different address, said “I need to get in touch with Paul i need to share some important information with him regarding ukraine investigation.” 
It added: “if I don’t get any reply from you iam gonaa pass it on to the fbi and ukrainian authorities inducing media.” 
There is no indication of when the texts were sent. The texts say President Trump met with an associate of the former Ukrainian President in 2012. (Pool/Getty Images) 
Manafort confirmed the authenticity of the texts coming from his daughter’s phone, but did not comment directly to Politico about what they said. He did, though, deny putting together the alleged 2012 meeting, and said he wasn’t working with Trump then. 
Leshchenko categorically denied the texts and said he had “nothing to do” with them. 
The White House did not directly comment on the texts but said the timeline could not work, but Trump and Manafort did not work together until 2016. 
The texts first surfaced weeks ago in an anonymous post on a dark website. 
Manafort was the first of three people tied to Trump’s political career to lose his job over ties or interactions with Russia. He resigned in August amidst investigations into his lobbying in Ukraine for pro-Russian interests. Manafort is now under investigation by the FBI, CIA and NSA. 
Former foreign policy advisor Carter Page and White House national security advisor Michael Flynn later left Trump’s team over Russian relations. 
Trump continues to face scrutiny for his apparent support of Russia, though he denies having any political or financial ties to the country. Join the Conversation:
